| Professional ratings "Heaven Sent" received critical acclaim, with the majority of critics declaring it the greatest episode of the ninth series, and possibly one of the greatest episodes in the show's run. Many instances of extremely high praise were aimed towards Steven Moffat's script, Rachel Talalay's direction, and Peter Capaldi's performance.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-auto-26)[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-auto1-27)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-avclub-28) The episode has a score of 89% on [Rotten Tomatoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), with an average score of 9.8, the highest average score of the series on the website. The site's consensus reads "Peter Capaldi turns in a one-man command performance in this episode's exploration of grief, and a surprise turn of events sets up an explosive season finale".[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-29) Patrick Mulkern of _[Radio Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Times "Radio Times")_ awarded the episode a perfect five star rating, saying that "Peter Capaldi's one-man show is an instant classic" and a "tour de force" for his magnificent performance. He also said that the episode's structure "works perfectly without ever seeming contrived" with Moffat's "trademark intricacy", and that Talalay "steeps the production in atmosphere and sustains the momentum right until the final revelations".[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-auto1-27) Calling the episode a "mind-bending masterpiece", Morgan Jeffery of [Digital Spy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_Spy "Digital Spy") stated that it was also "one of the most surreal episodes to date" with Moffat "cleverly subverting the expectations of a low-budget escapade, with a surplus of Capaldi awkwardly expressing his inner thoughts aloud." He said that the episode was "as far from big, broad, family-friendly entertainment as you can get", and that and "its rejection of the standard Doctor Who trappings might be too much for some"; but if viewers embrace the weirdness, then you'll end up captivated, calling it "demanding and intelligent science-fiction, the likes of which BBC One should be commended for airing".[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-30) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Peter_Capaldi_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/440px-Peter_Capaldi_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Peter_Capaldi_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg) [Peter Capaldi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Capaldi "Peter Capaldi") received widespread critical acclaim for his performance in the episode. Alasdair Wilkins of [The A.V. Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club") gave the episode an 'A', for the fifth time this season, writing "This season has been a remarkable achievement for the show, and, pending next week's finale, it's got a real chance to go down as the best season of the revival, topping even Matt Smith's debut in season five. And hey, maybe "Hell Bent" will be the perfect capper to this season, or maybe it won't. But the genius of the construction of this season's endgame is that "Hell Bent" could be an unmitigated disaster and it still wouldn't really undo the genius of "Heaven Sent" or "Face The Raven" before it."[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-auto2-17) Awarding the episode a score of 9.5 and deeming it "amazing" and the highest of the series, Scott Collura of [IGN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IGN "IGN") particularly praised the episode's conclusion by stating that "the realization that the sea of skulls is actually a sea of Doctor skulls" is a thrilling, brilliant twist, played beautifully with a "gentle guitar-driven score. He further praised Capaldi's performance, calling it "a breathtaking one-man show".[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-31) Referring to it as "an epic one man show", Tim Liew of _[Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro_(British_newspaper) "Metro (British newspaper)")_ also acclaimed the episode, saying that he "loved it". He particularly praised Steven Moffat and Peter Capaldi, stating that Moffat "takes a bold step by stripping his story back to its bare bones" and Capaldi "delivers 100%, carrying every scene"; he also praised the "superb new musical score" from series composer Murray Gold.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-auto-26) Mark Rozeman of _[Paste Magazine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paste_Magazine "Paste Magazine")_ also awarded the episode a perfect score (10.0), labeling it "a masterpiece of the highest order", whilst Ian Berriman of _[SFX Magazine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SFX_Magazine "SFX Magazine")_ also awarded full marks, saying "Heaven Sent stands as the best episode of the season so far: madly surreal, ingeniously baffling, immensely creepy and downright gruelling in its latter stages, with a tremendously impactful payoff".[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-pastemagazine.com-20)[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-ianberriman-23) ### Accolades \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)&action=edit§ion=6 "Edit section: Accolades")\] In 2016 "Heaven Sent" received a nomination for [Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation (Short Form)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_Award_for_Best_Dramatic_Presentation#Short_Form "Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation").[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-32) "Heaven Sent" is also the first episode of _Doctor Who_ to be submitted for nomination for a [Primetime Emmy Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award "Primetime Emmy Award"), due to [BBC America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_America "BBC America") being one of the series' co-producers. The episode was submitted to support Capaldi for [Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Lead_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series "Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series"), Moffat for [Outstanding Writing for a Drama Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Writing_for_a_Drama_Series "Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Drama Series"), and Talalay for [Outstanding Directing for a Drama Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outstanding_Directing_for_a_Drama_Series "Outstanding Directing for a Drama Series"), in addition to several other Creative Arts Emmys.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-33) In 2023, a _[Doctor Who Magazine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Who_Magazine "Doctor Who Magazine")_ fan poll voted _Heaven Sent_ as the best Doctor Who story of all time.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-34) _[The Daily Telegraph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ ranked the episode the 16th best of the entire programme in 2023.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-35) ## Soundtrack \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)&action=edit§ion=7 "Edit section: Soundtrack")\] Further information: [Doctor Who: Series 9 (soundtrack)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Who:_Series_9_(soundtrack) "Doctor Who: Series 9 (soundtrack)") Selected pieces of score from this episode, as composed by [Murray Gold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murray_Gold "Murray Gold"), comprise the entire third disc of the ninth series' 4-CD soundtrack, which was released on 27 April 2018 by Silva Screen Records.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-36)[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_note-37) ## Notes \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)&action=edit§ion=9 "Edit section: Notes")\] 1. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_ref-1 "Jump up")**The figure is not identified in the episode but called "Veil" in the credits. 2. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_ref-2 "Jump up")**Described as lasting four and a half billion years in the following week's episode " [Hell Bent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hell_Bent_(Doctor_Who) "Hell Bent (Doctor Who)")". 3. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_ref-3 "Jump up")**Referred to in the 2015 episodes " [The Magician's Apprentice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Magician%27s_Apprentice_(Doctor_Who) "The Magician's Apprentice (Doctor Who)")" and " [Face the Raven](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_the_Raven "Face the Raven")" as the Doctor's "last will and testament". 4. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Sent_(Doctor_Who)#cite_ref-5 "Jump up")**"Hell Bent" clarifies that the Doctor's declaration expresses his belief that the Hybrid is [Ashildr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashildr "Ashildr"), who became a human-Mire hybrid in " [The Girl Who Died](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Girl_Who_Died "The Girl Who Died")" and later adopted the name Me. ## 2. **Information**: 
   - Haydée Mercedes "La Negra" Sosa (9 July 1935 – 4 October 2009) was an influential Argentine singer, known across Latin America and globally. She began her career rooted in Argentine folk music and became a prominent figure in the El nuevo cancionero movement, giving a voice to many Latin American songwriters. 
   - Her music earned her nicknames such as "voice of the voiceless ones" and "the conscience of Latin America". Sosa's performances spanned major venues like New York's Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall, Paris's Théâtre Mogador, and even the Sistine Chapel in Vatican City.
   - Across her career, she received numerous accolades including six Latin Grammy awards and was a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador. 
   - Politically, Sosa was associated with leftist causes, opposing oppressive regimes and supporting the return of democracy in Argentina. Her arrest during Argentina's military dictatorship led to her temporary exile to Europe.
   - Sosa's artistry and activism left a significant legacy, and she remains celebrated posthumously, including through accolades like posthumous Grammy wins and tributes such as a Google Doodle in 2019. 

For more detailed reading, you can visit the Wikipedia page directly through the provided URL.

- [nueva canción](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nueva_canci%C3%B3n "Nueva canción") | | Instruments | Vocals | | Musical artist | **Haydée Mercedes** " **La Negra**" **Sosa** (Latin American Spanish:[\[meɾˈseðesˈsosa\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish"); 9 July 1935[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-birth-1) – 4 October 2009) was an [Argentine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentines "Argentines") singer who was popular throughout [Latin America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") and many countries outside the region. With her roots in [Argentine folk music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_music_of_Argentina "Folk music of Argentina"), Sosa became one of the preeminent exponents of _El nuevo cancionero_. She gave voice to songs written by many Latin American songwriters. Her music made people hail her as the "voice of the voiceless ones".[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-tmc-2) She was often called "the conscience of Latin America".[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-3) Sosa performed in venues such as the [Lincoln Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center "Lincoln Center") in New York City, the [Théâtre Mogador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador "Théâtre Mogador") in Paris, the [Sistine Chapel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel "Sistine Chapel") in Vatican City, as well as sold-out shows in New York's [Carnegie Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall "Carnegie Hall") and the Roman [Colosseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum "Colosseum") during her final decade of life. Her career spanned four decades and she was the recipient of six [Latin Grammy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy "Latin Grammy") awards (2000, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2009, 2011), including a [Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award "Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award") in 2004 and two posthumous [Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album "Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album") in 2009 and 2011. She won the [Premio Gardel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premios_Gardel "Premios Gardel") in 2000, the main musical award in Argentina. She served as an ambassador for [UNICEF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNICEF "UNICEF"). ## Life \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Life")\] Sosa was born on 9 July 1935, in [San Miguel de Tucumán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Miguel_de_Tucum%C3%A1n "San Miguel de Tucumán"), in the [northwestern Argentine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_Northwest "Argentine Northwest") province of [Tucumán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province "Tucumán Province"), of [mestizo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mestizo "Mestizo") ancestry. She was of French, Spanish and [Diaguita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaguita "Diaguita") descent.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4) Her nickname "la negra", which is a common nickname in Argentina for people with darker complexion, is a reference to her indigenous heritage.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5) Her parents, a day laborer and a washerwoman,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-6) were [Peronists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronism "Peronism"), although they never registered in the party, and she started her career as a singer for the [Peronist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronist_Party "Peronist Party") in [Tucuman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province "Tucumán Province") under the name Gladys Osorio.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-7) In 1950, at age fifteen, she won a singing competition organized by a local radio station and was given a contract to perform for two months.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) She recorded her first album, _[La Voz de la Zafra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_voz_de_la_zafra "La voz de la zafra")_, in 1959.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) A performance at the 1965 [Cosquín National Folklore Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosqu%C3%ADn_Festival "Cosquín Festival")—where she was introduced and brought to the stage while sitting in the audience by fellow folk singer [Jorge Cafrune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Cafrune "Jorge Cafrune")—[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-test-9) brought her to the attention of the Argentine public.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) Sosa and her first husband, [Manuel Oscar Matus](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Manuel_Oscar_Matus&action=edit&redlink=1 "Manuel Oscar Matus (page does not exist)"), with whom she had one son, were key players in the mid-60s _[nueva canción](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nueva_canci%C3%B3n "Nueva canción")_ movement (which was called _nuevo cancionero_ in Argentina).[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10) Her second record was _Canciones con Fundamento_, a collection of Argentine folk songs. [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Mercedes_Sosa%2C_F%C3%A9lix_Luna_y_Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez.jpg/440px-Mercedes_Sosa%2C_F%C3%A9lix_Luna_y_Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa,_F%C3%A9lix_Luna_y_Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez.jpg) Sosa with [Félix Luna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna "Félix Luna") and [Ariel Ramírez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez "Ariel Ramírez") (at the piano) Sosa "spent the late 1960s building her audience in Europe and among the cosmopolitan middle class in Buenos Aires, becoming in the process a much bigger star" than her contemporaries.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-11)In 1967, Sosa toured the United States and Europe with great success.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] In later years, she performed and recorded extensively, broadening her repertoire to include material from throughout Latin America. In the early 1970s, Sosa released two concept albums in collaboration with composer [Ariel Ramírez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez "Ariel Ramírez") and lyricist [Félix Luna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna "Félix Luna"): _Cantata Sudamericana_ and _Mujeres Argentinas_ (Argentine Women). She also recorded a tribute to Chilean musician [Violeta Parra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violeta_Parra "Violeta Parra") in 1971, including what was to become one of Sosa's signature songs, _[Gracias a la vida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gracias_a_la_vida "Gracias a la vida")_.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-ap-12) She further popularized of songs written by [Milton Nascimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento "Milton Nascimento") of Brazil and [Pablo Milanés](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Milan%C3%A9s "Pablo Milanés") and [Silvio Rodríguez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvio_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Silvio Rodríguez") both from [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba "Cuba").[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4) Throughout the decade, she released albums such as _Hasta la Victoria_ in 1972 and _Traigo un Pueblo_ _en mi Voz_ in 1973. They featured songs like "Cuando tenga la tierra", written by [Ariel Petrocelli](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ariel_Petrocelli&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ariel Petrocelli (page does not exist)") and Daniel Toro, which tackles political and social issues like wealth and land inequality.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13)[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-14) During the 1970s she was a part of two films by the director [Leopoldo Torre Nilsson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldo_Torre_Nilsson "Leopoldo Torre Nilsson"): _[El Santo de la Espada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Santo_de_la_Espada "El Santo de la Espada")_ in 1970 and _[Güemes, la tierra en armas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%BCemes:_la_tierra_en_armas "Güemes: la tierra en armas")_ in 1971, in which she portrayed [Juana Azurduy de Padilla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juana_Azurduy_de_Padilla "Juana Azurduy de Padilla"), the guerrilla military leader who fought for Argentine independence.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13)[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-15) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Mercedes_Sosa_2.jpg/500px-Mercedes_Sosa_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa_2.jpg) Sosa in 1972 After the [military junta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process "National Reorganization Process") of [Jorge Videla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Videla "Jorge Videla") came to power in 1976, the atmosphere in Argentina grew increasingly oppressive. Sosa faced death threats against both her and her family, but refused for many years to leave the country. At a concert in [La Plata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Plata "La Plata") in 1979, Sosa was searched and arrested on stage, along with all those attending the concert.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10) Their release came about through international intervention.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) Despite attempts to hold more concerts, she was officially barred from performing by the military regime.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5) Banned in her own country, she moved to Paris and then to [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid "Madrid").[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10)She has spoken publicly about her artistic and emotional struggles during this period of her life.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5) While in exile, she released the album _A Quien Doy_ in 1981. The album included a recording of the song "Cuando Me Acuerdo de Mi Pais" which was originally written by the prolific Chilean singer/songwriter, [Patricio Manns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricio_Manns "Patricio Manns"). The song, which he wrote while also in political exile, expresses the sorrow he felt from being separated from his homeland.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-16) She related to this feeling and struggled to continue recording and performing. In an interview with the New York Times, she said, “It was a mental problem, a problem of morale...It wasn’t my throat, or anything physical". [\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5) Sosa returned to Argentina from her exile in Europe in February of 1982,[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10) several months before the military regime collapsed as a result of the [Falklands War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falklands_War "Falklands War"), and gave a series of concerts at the _[Teatro Ópera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teatro_Opera "Teatro Opera")_ in Buenos Aires, where she invited many of her younger colleagues to share the stage. A double album of recordings from these performances became an instant best seller. She then traveled to perform in her home province of Tucuman. However, these performances were largely ignored by mainstream media in the country.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17) In subsequent years, Sosa continued to tour both in Argentina and abroad, performing in such venues as the [Lincoln Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center "Lincoln Center") in New York City and the _[Théâtre Mogador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador "Théâtre Mogador")_ in Paris. In poor health for much of the 1990s, she performed a comeback show in Argentina in 1998.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) In 1994, she played in the [Sistine Chapel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel "Sistine Chapel") in Vatican City.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4) In 2002, she sold out both [Carnegie Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall "Carnegie Hall") in New York and the [Colosseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum "Colosseum") in Rome in the same year.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Mercedes_Sosa.jpg/500px-Mercedes_Sosa.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa.jpg) Sosa in 1973 A supporter of [Perón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n "Juan Perón"), she favored leftist causes throughout her life. She supported President [Raul Alfonsin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn "Raúl Alfonsín") in the election of 1983 which marked the return of democracy in Argentina following the dictatorship. She referred to this election as "Argentina's Spring"[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-18) She opposed President [Carlos Menem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Menem "Carlos Menem"), who was in office from 1989 to 1999, and supported the election of [Néstor Kirchner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner "Néstor Kirchner"), who became president in 2003.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-19) Sosa was a [UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO_Goodwill_Ambassador "UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador") for Latin America and the Caribbean.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10)[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-20) Sosa disliked being identified as a protest singer.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-21)[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-22) While she was outright in her political stances, Sosa said the following on the position of the artist: > “An artist isn’t political in the party political sense – they have a constituency, which is their public – it is the poetry that matters most of all.” In a career spanning four decades, she worked with performers across several genres and generations, folk, opera, pop, rock, including [Martha Argerich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Argerich "Martha Argerich"), [Andrea Bocelli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli "Andrea Bocelli"), [David Broza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Broza "David Broza"), [Franco Battiato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Battiato "Franco Battiato"), [Jaime Roos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaime_Roos "Jaime Roos"), [Joan Baez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joan_Baez "Joan Baez"), [Francis Cabrel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Cabrel "Francis Cabrel"), [Gal Costa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gal_Costa "Gal Costa"), [Luz Casal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luz_Casal "Luz Casal"), [Lila Downs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lila_Downs "Lila Downs"), [Lucio Dalla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucio_Dalla "Lucio Dalla"), [Maria Farantouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Farantouri "Maria Farantouri"), [Lucecita Benitez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucecita_Benitez "Lucecita Benitez"), [Nilda Fernández](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nilda_Fern%C3%A1ndez "Nilda Fernández"), [Charly Garcia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charly_Garcia "Charly Garcia"), [León Gieco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Gieco "León Gieco"), [Gian Marco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gian_Marco "Gian Marco"), [Nana Mouskouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nana_Mouskouri "Nana Mouskouri"), [Pablo Milanés](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Milan%C3%A9s "Pablo Milanés"), [Holly Near](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holly_Near "Holly Near"), [Milton Nascimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento "Milton Nascimento"), [Pata Negra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pata_Negra "Pata Negra"), [Fito Páez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fito_P%C3%A1ez "Fito Páez"), [Franco De Vita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_De_Vita "Franco De Vita"), [Lourdes Pérez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lourdes_P%C3%A9rez "Lourdes Pérez"), [Luciano Pavarotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti "Luciano Pavarotti"), [Silvio Rodríguez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvio_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Silvio Rodríguez"), [Ismael Serrano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ismael_Serrano "Ismael Serrano"), [Shakira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shakira "Shakira"), [Sting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sting_(musician) "Sting (musician)"), [Caetano Veloso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caetano_Veloso "Caetano Veloso"),[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4) [Julieta Venegas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julieta_Venegas "Julieta Venegas"), [Gustavo Cerati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustavo_Cerati "Gustavo Cerati") and [Konstantin Wecker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konstantin_Wecker "Konstantin Wecker")[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10) Sosa participated in a 1999 production of [Ariel Ramírez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez "Ariel Ramírez")'s _Misa Criolla_.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-23) Her song _Balderrama_ is featured in the 2008 movie _[Che](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Che_(2008_film) "Che (2008 film)")_, starring [Benicio del Toro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benicio_del_Toro "Benicio del Toro") as the Argentine [Marxist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxist "Marxist") revolutionary [Che Guevara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Che_Guevara "Che Guevara").[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-24) Sosa was the co-chair of the [Earth Charter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth_Charter "Earth Charter") International Commission. ## Awards \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Awards")\] Sosa won the [Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album "Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album") in 2000 ( _Misa Criolla_),[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-25) 2003 ( _Acústico_),[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-26) 2006 ( _Corazón Libre_),[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-27) 2009 ( _[Cantora 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantora,_un_Viaje_%C3%8Dntimo "Cantora, un Viaje Íntimo")_, which also won [Best Recording Package](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Recording_Package "Latin Grammy Award for Best Recording Package") and was nominated for [Album of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year "Latin Grammy Award for Album of the Year")),[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-28) and 2011 ( _Deja La Vida Volar_),[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-29) as well as several international awards. In 1995, [Konex Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konex_Foundation "Konex Foundation") from Argentina granted her the Diamond [Konex Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konex_Award "Konex Award"), one of the most prestigious awards in Argentina, as the most important personality in the popular music of her country in the last decade.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-30) ## Death \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Death")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Funeral_de_Mercedes_Sosa.jpg/440px-Funeral_de_Mercedes_Sosa.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Funeral_de_Mercedes_Sosa.jpg) Mercedes Sosa lying in repose, with her family and President [Cristina Fernández de Kirchner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cristina_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Kirchner "Cristina Fernández de Kirchner") viewing Suffering from recurrent [endocrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endocrine_system "Endocrine system") and [respiratory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_system "Respiratory system") problems in later years, the 74-year-old Sosa was hospitalized in Buenos Aires on 18 September 2009.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-31) She died from [multiple organ failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_organ_failure "Multiple organ failure") on 4 October 2009, at 5:15 am.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-ap-12) She is survived by one son, Fabián Matus, born of her first marriage.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8)[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_singer_Mercedes_Sosa,_'voice_of_Latin_America,'_dies_at_74-32) He said: "She lived her 74 years to the fullest. She had done practically everything she wanted, she didn't have any type of barrier or any type of fear that limited her".[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_singer_Mercedes_Sosa,_'voice_of_Latin_America,'_dies_at_74-32) The hospital expressed its sympathies to her relatives.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_folk_legend_Mercedes_Sosa_dead_at_74-33) Her website featured the following: "Her undisputed talent, her honesty and her profound convictions leave a great legacy to future generations".[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_folk_icon_Sosa_dies_at_74-34) Her body was placed on display at the [National Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_National_Congress "Argentine National Congress") building in Buenos Aires for the public to pay their respects, and President Fernández de Kirchner ordered three days of national mourning.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_singer_Mercedes_Sosa,_'voice_of_Latin_America,'_dies_at_74-32)[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-35) Thousands had queued by the end of the day.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_folk_icon_Sosa_dies_at_74-34)[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-36) Sosa's obituary in _[The Daily Telegraph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ said she was "an unrivalled interpreter of works by her compatriot, the Argentine [Atahualpa Yupanqui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atahualpa_Yupanqui "Atahualpa Yupanqui"), and Chile's [Violeta Parra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violeta_Parra "Violeta Parra")".[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8) Helen Popper of [Reuters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") reported her death by saying she "fought South America's dictators with her voice and became a giant of contemporary Latin American music".[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Argentine_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-36) Sosa received three [Latin Grammy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy "Latin Grammy") nominations for her album, in 2009 . She went on to win Best Folk Album about a month after her death.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10) ## Tributes \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Tributes")\] In 2019, Sosa was celebrated by a [Google Doodle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Doodle "Google Doodle"). The doodle was showcased in [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina "Argentina"), [Chile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chile "Chile"), [Uruguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay "Uruguay"), [Paraguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraguay "Paraguay"), [Bolivia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivia "Bolivia"), [Peru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peru "Peru"), [Ecuador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador"), [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), [Iceland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iceland "Iceland"), Sweden, [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece "Greece"), [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel "Israel") and [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam").[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-37) In 2023, _[Rolling Stone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ ranked Sosa at number 160 on its list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-38) ## All the adults but me have been married, and no one is divorced or remarried, but my grandpa and my grandma's sister-in-law passed away last year. All living spouses are attending. My brother has two children that are still kids, my aunt has one six-year-old, and my grandma's brother's daughter has three kids under 12. I figure each adult will eat about 1.5 potatoes of mashed potatoes and each kid will eat about 1/2 a potato of mashed potatoes, except my second cousins don't eat carbs. The average potato is about half a pound, and potatoes are sold in 5-pound bags. How many whole bags of potatoes do I need? Just give the number.Please decompose the task into several sub-tasks and find the answer step-by-step.

# Word of the Day

: June 27, 2022

## jingoism

[play](https://www.merriam-webster.com/word-of-the-day/candidate-2022-06-27?pronunciation&lang=en_us&dir=j&file=jingoi01 "Listen to the pronunciation of jingoism")

nounJING-goh-iz-im

[Prev](https://www.merriam-webster.com/word-of-the-day/culminate-2022-06-26) [Next](https://www.merriam-webster.com/word-of-the-day/fulsome-2022-06-28)

* * *

## What It Means

_Jingoism_ is excessive patriotism or nationalism, especially when marked by a belligerent foreign policy.

// When the war began many people were caught up in a wave of _jingoism_.

[See the entry >](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/jingoism)

## jingoism in Context

"War is bad for culture. Not least of all because it turns our cultural institutions into bastions of _jingoism_." — Annie Levin, _The New York Observer_, 7 Mar. 2022

Pick the best words!

[PLAY](https://www.merriam-webster.com/games/blossom-word-game)

* * *

## Did You Know?

_Jingoism_ originated during the Russo-Turkish War of 1877-1878, when many British citizens were hostile toward Russia and felt Britain should intervene in the conflict. Supporters of the cause expressed their sentiments in a music-hall ditty with this refrain:

> We don't want to fight, yet by jingo if we do,
>
> We've got the ships, we've got the men,
>
> We've got the money, too!

Someone holding the attitude implied in the song became known as a _jingo_ or _jingoist_, and the attitude itself was dubbed _jingoism_. The _jingo_ in the tune is probably a euphemism for _Jesus_.

Solution: To determine whether the operation * is commutative, we need to check if for every pair of elements \( x \) and \( y \) from the set \( S = \{a, b, c, d, e\} \), \( x * y = y * x \).

We will go through each pair and identify any where \( x * y \neq y * x \). Let's analyze the table:

1. \( a * b = b \), \( b * a = c \): Not commutative
2. \( a * c = c \), \( c * a = a \): Not commutative
3. \( a * d = b \), \( d * a = b \): Commutative
4. \( a * e = d \), \( e * a = d \): Commutative
5. \( b * c = a \), \( c * b = b \): Not commutative
6. \( b * d = e \), \( d * b = e \): Commutative
7. \( b * e = c \), \( e * b = b \): Not commutative
8. \( c * d = b \), \( d * c = b \): Commutative
9. \( c * e = a \), \( e * c = a \): Commutative
10. \( d * e = e \), \( e * d = d \): Not commutative

From the analysis, the pairs where \( x * y \neq y * x \) are:

- \( (a, b) \) and \( (b, a) \)
- \( (a, c) \) and \( (c, a) \)
- \( (b, c) \) and \( (c, b) \)
- \( (b, e) \) and \( (e, b) \)
- \( (d, e) \) and \( (e, d) \)

The elements involved in these pairs are: \( a, b, c, d, e \).

Thus, the entire set \( S \) is involved in the counter-examples proving * is not commutative. Therefore, the answer is:

Solution: a, b, c, d, e

question:
You are Van Helsing, a renowned vampire hunter. A Count of Moldova, Lațcu IV, son of  Costea, has tasked you with investigating the village of Șirnea in neighboring Wallachia. The Count's advisors have reported that a vampire was spotted crossing the border near the village, and would like you to investigate it.

You travel to the village of Șirnea, and you begin your investigation. One night, just before dawn, you catch a glimpse of a man in a long black cape with red lining leaping from roof-top to roof-top with superhuman agility. It's a vampire! You try to chase the creature back to its home, but the creature is too fast. However, because of the remoteness of the village, you know with absolute certainty that the vampire must be a resident of the village. You decide that your best course of action will be to visit all 100 residents of the town during the day. You know something about vampires and humans that will make your investigation possible; humans always tell the truth, but vampires always lie.

In the afternoon, you go from house to house, speaking with all 100 residents of Șirnea. You ask everyone the same question: "How many vampires are living in Șirnea". Everyone in the village gives the same response, "At least one of us is a human."

How many residents of Șirnea have been turned into vampires?Please decompose the task into several sub-tasks and find the answer step-by-step.

I'm making a grocery list for my mom, but she's a professor of botany and she's a real stickler when it comes to categorizing things. I need to add different foods to different categories on the grocery list, but if I make a mistake, she won't buy anything inserted in the wrong category. Here's the list I have so far:

milk, eggs, flour, whole bean coffee, Oreos, sweet potatoes, fresh basil, plums, green beans, rice, corn, bell pepper, whole allspice, acorns, broccoli, celery, zucchini, lettuce, peanuts

I need to make headings for the fruits and vegetables. Could you please create a list of just the vegetables from my list? If you could do that, then I can figure out how to categorize the rest of the list into the appropriate categories. But remember that my mom is a real stickler, so make sure that no botanical fruits end up on the vegetable list, or she won't get them when she's at the store. Please alphabetize the list of vegetables, and place each item in a comma separated list.Please decompose the task into several sub-tasks and find the answer step-by-step.

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vegetables#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

This is a [dynamic list](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Lists#Dynamic_lists "Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists") and may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by [adding missing items](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/List_of_vegetables "Special:EditPage/List of vegetables") with [reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources").

This is a list of plants that have a [culinary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooking "Cooking") role as [vegetables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegetable "Vegetable"). "Vegetable" can be used in several senses, including culinary, [botanical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botanical "Botanical") and legal. This list includes botanical [fruits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruit "Fruit") such as pumpkins, and does not include [herbs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herb "Herb"), [spices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spice "Spice"), [cereals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cereal "Cereal") and most [culinary fruits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fruits "List of fruits") and [culinary nuts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nut_(fruit) "Nut (fruit)"). [Edible fungi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edible_mushroom "Edible mushroom") are not included in this list.

Legal vegetables are defined for regulatory, tax and other purposes. An example would include the [tomato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomato "Tomato"), which is [botanically a berry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berry_(botany) "Berry (botany)") (fruit), but culinarily a vegetable according to the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States "United States").

args.question: Is celery a botanical fruit or vegetable?

tool_calls.result:
Here is the relevant information regarding whether celery is a botanical fruit or vegetable:

1. **Wikipedia: Celery**
   - **URL**: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celery)
   - **Information**: Celery, scientifically known as Apium graveolens, belongs to the family Apiaceae and is considered a vegetable. The plant has been used as a vegetable since ancient times. It is primarily composed of water but contains a significant amount of vitamin K and negligible fat. The plant has various cultivated forms, including stalk celery, leaf celery, and celeriac, each bred for different edible parts like stalks, leaves, and large, edible hypocotyls. Celery is typically consumed raw in salads, cooked in soups and stews, or juiced, and its seeds are used as a spice.

The classification of celery as a vegetable is consistent with its historical and culinary use as well as its botanical characteristics as part of the Apiaceae family.

# Computer Science > Computers and Society **arXiv:2207.01510** (cs) \[Submitted on 8 Jun 2022\] # Title:Fairness in Agreement With European Values: An Interdisciplinary Perspective on AI Regulation Authors: [Alejandra Bringas Colmenarejo](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Colmenarejo,+A+B), [Luca Nannini](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Nannini,+L), [Alisa Rieger](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Rieger,+A), [Kristen M. Scott](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Scott,+K+M), [Xuan Zhao](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Zhao,+X), [Gourab K. Patro](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Patro,+G+K), [Gjergji Kasneci](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Kasneci,+G), [Katharina Kinder-Kurlanda](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Kinder-Kurlanda,+K) View a PDF of the paper titled Fairness in Agreement With European Values: An Interdisciplinary Perspective on AI Regulation, by Alejandra Bringas Colmenarejo and 7 other authors [View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2207.01510) > Abstract:With increasing digitalization, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming ubiquitous. AI-based systems to identify, optimize, automate, and scale solutions to complex economic and societal problems are being proposed and implemented. This has motivated regulation efforts, including the Proposal of an EU AI Act. This interdisciplinary position paper considers various concerns surrounding fairness and discrimination in AI, and discusses how AI regulations address them, focusing on (but not limited to) the Proposal. We first look at AI and fairness through the lenses of law, (AI) industry, sociotechnology, and (moral) philosophy, and present various perspectives. Then, we map these perspectives along three axes of interests: (i) Standardization vs. Localization, (ii) Utilitarianism vs. Egalitarianism, and (iii) Consequential vs. Deontological ethics which leads us to identify a pattern of common arguments and tensions between these axes. Positioning the discussion within the axes of interest and with a focus on reconciling the key tensions, we identify and propose the roles AI Regulation should take to make the endeavor of the AI Act a success in terms of AI fairness concerns. | | | | --- | --- | | Comments: | In proceedings of AAAI/ACM Conference AIES 2022 ( [this https URL](https://doi.org/10.1145/3514094.3534158)) | | Subjects: | Computers and Society (cs.CY) | | Cite as: | [arXiv:2207.01510](https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.01510) \[cs.CY\] | | | (or [arXiv:2207.01510v1](https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.01510v1) \[cs.CY\] for this version) | | | [https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2207.01510](https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2207.01510)

# Physics > Physics and Society **arXiv:1608.03637** (physics) \[Submitted on 11 Aug 2016\] # Title:Phase transition from egalitarian to hierarchical societies driven by competition between cognitive and social constraints Authors: [Nestor Caticha](https://arxiv.org/search/physics?searchtype=author&query=Caticha,+N), [Rafael Calsaverini](https://arxiv.org/search/physics?searchtype=author&query=Calsaverini,+R), [Renato Vicente](https://arxiv.org/search/physics?searchtype=author&query=Vicente,+R) View a PDF of the paper titled Phase transition from egalitarian to hierarchical societies driven by competition between cognitive and social constraints, by Nestor Caticha and 1 other authors [View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1608.03637) > Abstract:Empirical evidence suggests that social structure may have changed from hierarchical to egalitarian and back along the evolutionary line of humans. We model a society subject to competing cognitive and social navigation constraints. The theory predicts that the degree of hierarchy decreases with encephalization and increases with group size. Hence hominin groups may have been driven from a phase with hierarchical order to a phase with egalitarian structures by the encephalization during the last two million years, and back to hierarchical due to fast demographical changes during the Neolithic. The dynamics in the perceived social network shows evidence in the egalitarian phase of the observed phenomenon of Reverse Dominance. The theory also predicts for modern hunter-gatherers in mild climates a trend towards an intermediate hierarchy degree and a phase transition for harder ecological conditions. In harsher climates societies would tend to bemore egalitarian if organized in small groups but more hierarchical if in large groups. The theoretical model permits organizing the available data in the cross-cultural record (Ethnographic Atlas, N=248 cultures) where the symmetry breaking transition can be clearly seen. | | | | --- | --- | | Comments: | 23 pages, 8 figures | | Subjects: | Physics and Society (physics.soc-ph); Social and Information Networks (cs.SI) | | Cite as: | [arXiv:1608.03637](https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.03637) \[physics.soc-ph\] | | | (or [arXiv:1608.03637v1](https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.03637v1) \[physics.soc-ph\] for this version) | | | [https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1608.03637](https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1608.03637)

## Syntax

Unlambda is written in a parenthesis-free prefix notation; parentheses are neither necessary nor allowed. Instead, the `` ` `` prefix operator is used to apply a function to an argument; if _f_ and _x_ are expressions, then `` `fx`` is an expression that applies _f_ to the argument _x_. Other than this operator, every other element of the language is essentially a _combinator_, denoting a function taking exactly one other function as argument and returning another.

For example, the combinator `S I I (S I I)`, which reduces to itself, could be encoded with the following Unlambda expression:

````
```sii``sii

````

## Combinators

The following combinators are defined:

**s** takes three arguments (via currying) and applies each of the first two to the third and applies those to each other and returns the result, that is, \`\`\`sxyz evaluates to \`\`xz\`yz.

**k** takes two arguments (via currying) and returns the first.

**i** takes one argument and returns it.

**v** takes one argument and returns v.

**.x** (where x is any character) takes one argument and returns it, with the "side effect" of printing x.

**r** is an abbreviation for . _newline_.

**d** as a function simply takes two arguments and applies the first to the second, but in an expression it has a special effect: the second argument must be evaluated before the first. While d has only one argument, that argument is not evaluated. (For example, \`\`d\`.xi\`.yi evaluates \`.yi _first_, outputting y and returning i. Now since the second argument has been evaluated, d acts like the identity function i, so we have \`\`i\`.xii, which evaluates to i and outputs x: the whole program outputs yx rather than xy due to d's special order-of-evaluation rules.)

**c** takes one argument. When applied, c creates a continuation out of the program's current state and applies the argument to this continuation.

A continuation is a special function that, when applied to an argument, "goes back in time" to when the continuation was created and makes the c function that created it return the continuation's argument instead of what it normally would. An example:

```
``cii     (This function creates a continuation (`*i). See meta-notation below.)
``i(`*i)i (Now the function i is being applied to the continuation.)
`(`*i)i   (i returns (`*i) as normal.)
          (Applying (`*i) takes us "back in time"...)
`ii       (...and changes the original `ci to the argument that (`*i) was applied to, which is i.)
i         (`ii is evaluated, returning i as normal.)

```

The following combinators were added in Unlambda version 2:

**e** takes one argument. When applied, e exits the program, possibly providing its argument as the program's result. Put another way, e is an abbreviation for a continuation, the one in which the whole program is run.

**@** takes one argument. When applied, it tries to read a character of input, making it the _current character_. It then applies its argument to i if successful or to v if not (for example on EOF).

**?x** takes one argument. When applied, it compares the current character to x, and then applies its argument to i if equal and to v if not (or if no character has been read, or EOF has been reached).

**\|** takes one argument. When applied, it applies its argument to .x, where x is the current character, or to v if no character has been read, or EOF has been reached.

## Complexity class

Because Unlambda embeds the SKI basis, which embeds every lambda term, it is Turing-complete; in particular, it is undecidable whether a given Unlambda expression halts when evaluated or even whether it has a normal form.

## Examples

Several more examples are included in the Unlambda distribution.

### Palindromes

This program is a palindromic [Hello, World](https://esolangs.org/wiki/Hello,_world! "Hello, world!") program inspired by [this Stack Overflow thread](https://web.archive.org/web/20141011143701/http://stackoverflow.com/questions/659752/programming-challenge-can-you-code-a-hello-world-program-as-a-palindrome) _(from the [Wayback Machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayback_Machine "wikipedia:Wayback Machine"); retrieved on 11 October 2014)_:

````````````````
`.d`.c`.d`.c`.d`.c`.d``e
`````````````.H.e.l.l.o.,. .W.o.r.l.dii```````````````iid.l.r.o.W. .,.o.l.l.e.H.`````````````
e``d.`c.`d.`c.`d.`c.`d.`

````````````````

Note that this program triggers a bug in at least the C interpreter ( `e` doesn't actually exit as it should), so use another interpreter.

Instead of using `e` to avoid applying the padding functions, we can use `d` plus the fact that applying a `?x` function to `v` has no effect:

````````````````
`?d`?c`?d`?c`?d`?c`?d``v````````````.H.e.l.l.o.,. .W.o.r.l.di`d
```````````````
d`id.l.r.o.W. .,.o.l.l.e.H.````````````v``d?`c?`d?`c?`d?`c?`d?`

````````````````

The above also works in the C interpreter. Both of these methods can be used with a general program, as long as you avoid reverse syntax errors. The substitution of `[?.]x` with ``` ``k[?.]x.i``` can be used for this.

### [Hello, world!](https://esolangs.org/wiki/Hello,_world! "Hello, world!")

## Meta-notation

For reasoning about Unlambda programs, or for displaying partially evaluated expressions, it is useful to have a notation for ongoing computations and continuations. These suggestions are not part of the language proper, but can be added to debugging implementations.

- To denote a continuation, write an expression in parentheses, with a \* character at the spot where a value may be returned.

If the continuation is applied to an argument, that argument is substituted for the \*, and the resulting expression in parentheses replaces the whole program.

Using the e combinator and considering \* as a variable, this notation may be taken as an abbreviation for a lambda expression: ( _expression_) = ^\*\`e _expression_. Alternatively, it may be considered an "inside-out" printing of the actual continuation structure used by some implementations.

In order for a continuation to have the intended meaning, the \* should be at a spot in the expression where the next evaluation may take place, that is, everything before it should have been already evaluated, and it should not be inside a promise ('d _expression_).
There might be more than one \* in a continuation, but only one is not nested in further parentheses (representing embedded continuations).

- To distinguish between expressions and already evaluated functions, use a different notation for the latter, replacing the \` character by ' (a forward quote).

An evaluated function will then not contain \` except after a 'd (because d "freezes" unevaluated expressions) or inside an embedded continuation.

- To shorten notation or to make structure sharing explicit, define names for common subexpressions.

We borrow the $v notation from the unlambdaifier tool, and let $v= _expression_ or _function_. The assignment may be listed separately or for example embedded in the expression at the first spot where the subexpression is used. To embed continuation variables in this way we may use an inside-out notation such as (=$x:...) for definition and ($x:...) for referencing.

A shorter notation for inside-out continuation variables is to use other types of brackets, such as \[...\] or <...>.

- Using these notations it is possible to evaluate Unlambda programs in an equational style. If you wish to substitute such equations into expressions, note that instances of the (...) notation in the equation also need to be substituted by the continuation of the subexpression.

For example, the equation \`cc = (\*) is valid. When substituting this into \`c\`cc, we must also substitute (\`c\*) for (\*), giving \`c\`cc = \`c(\`c\*). Note that we can only do this for subexpressions that are next in order for evaluation, at a spot where a \* would be allowed. This restriction does not apply for equations that do not contain the (...) notation.

Here are some relevant results related to SPFMV and SPCSV virus testing in the Pearl of Africa, focusing on publications and research papers from 2016:

1. **Title: Effects of Sweet Potato Feathery Mottle Virus and Sweet Potato Chlorotic Stunt Virus**
   - **Description:** Sweet potato feathery mottle virus (SPFMV) and Sweet potato chlorotic stunt virus (SPCSV) are common viruses infecting sweetpotato in Uganda. Research was conducted using field plots with graft inoculated plants of virus-free cultivars to assess the effect on yield and quality of sweetpotatoes in two agro-ecologies.
   - **URL:** [Link to Wiley Online Library](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/jph.12451)

2. **Title: Evaluation of Diagnostic Methods for Sweetpotato Viruses (PDF)**

   - **URL:** [Link to PDF on Sweetpotato Knowledge](http://www.sweetpotatoknowledge.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/SASHA-PMT-Diagnostic-methods-June-2016-BWW.pdf)

3. **Title: Sweetpotato Virus Diagnostics and Effects in Sub-Saharan Africa (PDF)**
   - **Description:** This research document reviews more than 30 described viruses infecting sweetpotato, with focus on SPFMV and SPCSV, highlighting their widespread impact and role in the sweetpotato virus disease (SPVD).
   - **URL:** [Link to PDF on Sweetpotato Knowledge](http://www.sweetpotatoknowledge.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/15.-Jan-Kreuze-Improving-Sweetpotato-Virus-Diagnostics.pdf)

These results provide a foundational understanding of the testing and impacts of SPFMV and SPCSV on sweetpotato in the African context, particularly Uganda.
